newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: DAIRY BRANDS WARNS OF MILK PRICE SQUEEZE.
newsitem.headline: DAIRY BRANDS WARNS OF MILK PRICE SQUEEZE.

text.p: Dairy Brands Limited warned on Monday it saw a negative impact on its current year's financial performance if milk prices are reduced as forecast and co-operative premiums remain at similar levels.
The largest cooperative player, the Dairy Board, has forecast a full-year milk price of between NZ$2.90 and $3.05 per kilogramme of milk solids.
Dairy Brands noted that this price represents a further reduction on that achieved in the 1996/97 season.
"Should the co-operative premium be maintained at similar levels, the resultant overall milk price will negatively impact Dairy Brands' performance in the current year," it said.
Chairman Ruth Richardson noted in comments accompanying the firm's results for the first eight months of the year that the company wanted to see improved performance across the industry.
"The dairy industry is a vital component in the New Zealand economy and the country can ill afford to have it performing at anything other than its optimal level.
"It is Dairy Brands' view that the current structure of the industry is constraining its ability to maximise its performance," she added.
Dairy Brands said it believed the industry had a duty to expose its performance to competitive pressures.
Several ministers have commented lately on the need for reform at the Dairy Board, though no formal process has started yet.
